text: I'm a former commissioner of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission.
I'm also a professor here at Stanford Law School,
where I'm a professor of law and business,
and also run the Rock Center on Corporate Governance.
In addition, Bill Sharp and I several years ago founded Financial Engines,
which became the world's largest robo advisor.
We currently manage about a $175 billion.
So the intersection of technology and
securities regulation has always been a large part of my area of interest.
Given that background and everything that's happening here in Silicon Valley,
it's easy to understand how Bitcoin, Blockchain,
and all issues related to Crypto pretty much are
percolated to the fore in terms of the scholarship that I'm doing,
conversations here in the valley, and you know,
research and speaking around a wide range of topics.
